Forensic investigations suggest a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source caused a fireball. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to CAF for complaints lodged during the 2015 tournament, stemming from a controversial penalty decision in their quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea. Morocco, initially banned and fined $1 million for refusing to host the 2015 event due to Ebola concerns, had their ban overturned by CAS and fine reduced to $50,000. Both nations are now set to compete in the 2017 qualifiers, with Tunisia aiming for a record 13th consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

In the 95th minute of a 3-1 Chelsea win at Etihad Stadium, a mass fracas led to Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho being sent off. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, his second such dismissal this season, after a late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz. Fernandinho was banned for three matches following a clash with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas, who faces no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's role in the incident. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

**Concise Summary:**

Wales and other UK regions have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. A pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath Port Talbot focuses on patients suspected of having cancer but showing no urgent symptoms, aiming to reduce diagnosis delays. Inspired by Denmark's diagnostic systems, the plan allows GPs to refer patients to a diagnostic centre at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days, with hopes of same-day tests. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms in Cwm Taf receive a timely diagnosis. The trial, developed post-visits to Aarhus, Denmark, aims to improve early detection for asymptomatic patients. If successful, the six-month pilot will be rolled out across other health boards in the region.

England defeated Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with their second-largest run victory over Pakistan. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his scores of 254 and 71*, along with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it "extraordinary." Pakistan struggled, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series. Misbah acknowledged their poor shot selection and lack of confidence. England is in a strong position, but Michael Vaughan predicts a tight series ahead. Pakistan will play a tour game before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland, head coach of the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, has included interim coach Rob Howley in his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales' summer tour, marking his third time in this role. McBryde expressed honor and excitement for the opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is appointing assistant coaches for the tour and expects to confirm the full management team soon. WRU chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches in the Lions tour will benefit Welsh rugby by providing valuable development opportunities in challenging environments.

Hull City ended a six-game losing streak with a 2-1 comeback win against Southampton. Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton ahead, but Hull's Robert Snodgrass, introduced from the bench, equalized in the 61st minute and assisted Michael Dawson's winning header shortly after. Despite Southampton's late push, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall and defender Sam Clucas made crucial saves and a goalline clearance to secure the victory. The win, Hull's first since August 20, keeps them in the bottom three but provides a morale boost. Southampton, coming off a Europa League win, struggled to maintain momentum and concentration.

A fatal collision occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, involving a motorcyclist and a tractor. The motorcyclist, a local resident, was killed, while the tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses and have closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

Macedonia's President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, citing the need to end political turmoil ahead of June elections. His decision was criticized by the opposition, led by Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and urged protests, and by EU officials, including Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership aspirations. The crisis stems from recordings released since 2015, allegedly exposing government corruption, vote-rigging, and cover-ups, which the government denies. Ivanov defended his move as protecting national interests, while Zaev continues to accuse the government of widespread misconduct.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea City against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager swiftly, with Paul Clement as the top candidate. The club faces relegation concerns, acknowledging the difficulty of returning to the Premier League if demoted. Swansea, promoted in 2011, rose from near-bankruptcy and Football League relegation threats in 2003. Curtis attributes the team's decline to frequent managerial changes since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure, diluting the "Swansea Way." Despite challenges, Curtis believes the current squad can avoid relegation, emphasizing the club's history and importance to the region.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after a 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient, despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. Armand Gnanduillet's winner kept Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who first reached the Football League in 2007, have struggled defensively and offensively this season, with a poor goal difference and reduced goal output from veteran striker Cureton. Manager John Still, in his third spell at the club, is committed to securing promotion next season. Orient, now under interim manager Andy Hessenthaler after Kevin Nolan's departure, remain two points off the play-off spots, with Hessenthaler emphasizing professionalism and the need to win games to achieve their goals.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain, is returning to the club as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring from professional football in November. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and won multiple trophies during his career, has expressed his ambition to become a manager in the future. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp praised Gerrard's appointment, highlighting his playing experience and potential for growth in coaching. Gerrard is also working towards his UEFA A coaching license, a requirement for managing in the Premier League.
Morton secured a comfortable win with goals from McManus (2), Ross Forbes, and Denny Johnstone. Alloa briefly responded through Kyle McAusland but couldn't prevent Morton's victory.

Ofsted has uncovered evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three illegal schools in Birmingham, which have been closed. The owners are under investigation, and running such schools can result in a jail term of up to 51 weeks. Ofsted and ministers are concerned about unregulated schools, particularly those exploiting the legal right to home educate, with 18 such places visited in Muslim communities in the Midlands. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw warns this is likely the "tip of the iceberg," with risks of abuse or radicalization. The government is consulting on increased regulation for places teaching over 6-8 hours weekly and has funded a team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups. The Education Secretary plans to prosecute identified unregistered schools, emphasizing that children in such settings is unacceptable.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the region's first new distillery in nearly 200 years. Led by distiller Kate Macinnes, it aims to highlight the Scottish Borders' local flavors and "terroir" using wild botanicals from the Teviot valley. The distillery operates on a small scale, housed in a cowshed, with one of the UK's smallest production stills. Named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders heroine from the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, the gin reflects the region's history and its strong female production team. The project complements the existing Scottish Borders Brewery on-site, aligning with the ethos of local sourcing. John Henderson of Born in the Borders expressed excitement for the distillery's launch and its use of local ingredients.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 after Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal alcohol limit, reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm in Rothwell, near Leeds. Green, 51, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law as the incident occurred on private land. Harry’s mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed profound grief, emphasizing the irreversible impact on her family and advocating against drunk driving. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) described Green’s actions as "reckless" in an "extremely tragic case."

Luis Suarez, the 27-year-old Uruguay striker, can now train and play in friendly matches with Barcelona, following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). While he remains banned from competitive matches (including eight remaining international games), he can participate in "football-related activities," attend matches, and engage in promotional activities. Suarez's competitive Barcelona debut is expected on October 26 against Real Madrid. CAS deemed FIFA's initial ban from all football activity "excessive," allowing Suarez to train to avoid post-suspension impact. He will play in Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia. Suarez's legal team and Fifpro argue the sanctions are disproportionate, but CAS upheld FIFA's decision with modifications. Suarez, who moved to Barcelona for £75m, has a history of suspensions, including for biting incidents and racial abuse.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene of Lithuania. The race involved a 380-metre obstacle course with haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. Competitors can be of any gender combination, and marriage is not required. The winners will advance to the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government is replacing the paper-based car tax disc system with an electronic system in October 2014, allowing monthly direct debit payments. Concerns about job losses among the 5,000 DVLA workers were raised, but Transport Minister Stephen Hammond assured that changes would primarily involve job role adjustments and training for new processes, with any reductions in staff managed through redeployment rather than redundancies. Swansea East AM Mike Hedges welcomed the assurances, acknowledging the benefits of the new system while expressing disappointment over reduced job opportunities at the DVLA.

The passage discusses tensions between Hungary and the EU over three contentious laws: tight controls on asylum seekers, restrictions on NGOs, and a higher education law that threatens the Central European University (CEU). Hungary's Foreign Minister, Péter Szijjártó, asserts that these laws are domestic issues and rejects EU interference. Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary, including stripping it of its voting rights, which requires unanimous approval. The EU criticizes Hungary's policies, particularly its treatment of asylum seekers and the potential closure of CEU, founded by George Soros. Protests against the laws have occurred in Hungary, and the EU has warned of impending action if no positive changes are made.

The live-action adaptation of *Beauty and the Beast* features Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. The cast includes Oscar-winners Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts and Kevin Kline as Maurice, with Josh Gad as LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, the film began production in May at Shepperton Studios and was released in U.S. cinemas on March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist for *The Sunday Times*, passed away after battling multiple cancers, which he referred to as the "full English" of cancers. Known for his dazzling, fearless writing and wit, Gill was celebrated as "a giant among journalists" by colleagues and peers. His final column, addressing his diagnosis, was published posthumously. Gill's career was marked by his unique style, overcoming dyslexia to become a celebrated writer, though his work often sparked controversy due to provocative remarks. Tributes highlighted his brilliance, kindness, and impact on journalism. He is survived by his partner, Nicola Formby, and four children from previous relationships.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, Mongolia's capital. Russian news reported he was struck with a bottle and kicked in the face, resulting in a coma for about 10 days. The Russian embassy is investigating but disputes local press reports as "distorted." Sukhbaatar wore a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika, a symbol pre-dating Nazi use in Mongolia. His father and lawyer denied claims he shouted "Heil Hitler" and emphasized the swastika's cultural significance. The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been arrested, with police citing the injury as not serious, not diplomatic immunity. The case remains under investigation.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against Heathrow Airport's expansion plans on Monday, staging a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. Charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area, they will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police announced a review of airport security in response.

Glamorgan's innings was anchored by Nick Selman's 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, despite regular wickets from Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles in cloudy conditions. Selman's innings marked a return to form after a string of low scores. Aneurin Donald contributed 36 off 30 balls, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten secured a consolation bonus point for Glamorgan. Gloucestershire's innings ended evenly balanced in challenging conditions. Glamorgan, led by Michael Hogan in Jacques Rudolph's absence, saw Selman reflect on his struggles and relief at scoring runs, while Taylor highlighted the bowlers' efforts and the challenges ahead for Gloucestershire's batsmen.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making threats to ambush and shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary during online chats with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. He claimed he planned to make a false report to lure officers to the scene, but prosecutors noted the threats were made while he was drunk and had no intention to follow through. Hughes has a prior conviction for possessing a firearm (2009) and was on bail for firearms offenses at the time, though he was later cleared. He is currently in custody awaiting sentencing.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire in a cricket match, posting a score of 255-7 thanks to a 130-run partnership between Davies (90) and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire's chase was derailed by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket haul, including key dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire fell short, all out for 236. Surrey's skipper praised the team's collective effort, highlighting Davies and Foakes' partnership as pivotal. Yorkshire's captain expressed disappointment, acknowledging their strong white-ball performance but inability to deliver in crucial moments.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, reported flooding at 07:00 BST as its onboard pump failed to manage the incoming water. Holyhead coastguards and the RNLI lifeboat crew responded by providing an additional pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead for safety.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies and exams scheduled for May. Despite her absence from the Commonwealths, Muir remains focused on completing her degree and looks forward to future competitions, including potentially the World Indoor Championships in March and multiple Olympics. She recently achieved a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, finishing sixth, and expressed optimism about her future in the sport.

Here’s a concise summary of the passage:

Robbie Savage analyzes Liverpool's struggles this season, attributing them to unrealistic expectations after last season's overachievement, poor transfer decisions (especially in attack), and defensive weaknesses. He highlights the loss of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injuries as key factors in their goal-scoring decline. Savage criticizes Brendan Rodgers' striker signings (Balotelli, Lambert, Borini) for lacking work-rate and quality. He notes Liverpool's drop in first-half goals, set-piece effectiveness, and midfield intensity compared to 2013-14. Defensively, he points out the lack of leadership and Simon Mignolet's shortcomings as a goalkeeper. Savage suggests a lineup for the Chelsea match, advocating for dropping Dejan Lovren and emphasizing the need for full-back contributions and midfield energy. He predicts a Chelsea win due to their superior form but praises Steven Gerrard's resilience and believes he can still contribute long-term, despite physical and mental challenges.

A £45m educational facility in Kilmarnock will include primary, secondary, and Gaelic schools, plus a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after renowned writer William McIlvanney, a Kilmarnock native, to honor his passion for education and his literary legacy. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," authored the Laidlaw trilogy and other acclaimed works, and was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster. He passed away on December 5th.

An area near a town's swimming pool was evacuated, and nearby residents were advised to stay indoors as a precaution due to a British sea mine, likely from the 1940s or 1950s, found in the river. An exclusion zone was established on the river and at sea, disrupting ferry services and small boat operations. Experts from the Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit are working to safely relocate the mine, as its explosive content is uncertain due to deterioration. Local authorities thanked residents for their patience during the evacuation and safety procedures.

UK Sport has allocated £345m to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, setting Team GB a target of 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Funding cuts include cycling (£4m reduction) and the complete removal of badminton funding, despite its bronze medal in Rio, sparking criticism from Badminton England. Judo, which also won bronze, received a slight funding increase. New Olympic sports like baseball/softball, karate, and skateboarding await funding decisions based on medal potential. Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball remain unfunded, prompting criticism of UK Sport's focus on individual medal-winning sports.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine and seven storeys). Despite objections from English Heritage and local residents over the development's scale and impact on the area's historic character, councillors approved the plans (7-3 vote), citing benefits for tourism and elderly living. The project, supported by 246 letters, will replace Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View hotels with a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely while off-duty in Brecon. Vallely, who had been on a drinking binge and claimed to be the "hardest man in Brecon," punched and beat Boyd outside a bar, dragging his unconscious body away before fleeing. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of involvement. Boyd, a soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was described by his family as a loving, caring, and loyal individual with a promising career cut short. The attack, deemed "despicable" by police, shocked the community, with Boyd’s family emphasizing the outpouring of support from Brecon as a testament to the town’s strength.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by "mutual agreement" following an error that prevented voters from casting their ballots at all 155 polling stations in the borough due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, with findings to be presented publicly by the end of May. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over, and the investigation will also review arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a match highlighted by fine goals and tactical adjustments. Josh Gillies opened the scoring for Gateshead with a free-kick, but Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with a set-piece before halftime. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a headed goal from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half improvement, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his side's performance after halftime. The match featured several missed opportunities and substitutions, with Gateshead ultimately holding on for the victory.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks 96 countries based on the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60. Norway ranks first, while Afghanistan and Mozambique are the lowest-ranked countries.

The OneWeb project aims to create a global broadband network using a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, with a focus on connecting every school worldwide. This requires a significant shift in satellite manufacturing, emphasizing high volume and low cost, akin to car and plane production. Airbus, initially skeptical, is now leading this effort with assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and Florida, aiming to produce three satellites per shift for under a million dollars each. The project involves a massive rocket campaign, primarily using Soyuz vehicles, to deploy satellites into orbit, with the goal of having over 800 satellites by mid-decade. OneWeb faces competition from SpaceX, Boeing, and others but has secured $1.7 billion in equity and is working on additional financing. The UK plays a key role as the licensing authority and a major revenue source, with OneWeb committing to advanced debris mitigation measures, including de-orbiting satellites within two years. The initiative could revolutionize satellite manufacturing, though bespoke platforms will still be needed for specialized missions.

The UK government's spending review has put significant pressure on Scotland's public expenditure, with Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney arguing that cuts since 2010 will reduce Scotland's discretionary budget by 12.5% in real terms by 2019-20. Despite the UK government claiming Scotland will have £390m more to spend next year, Swinney highlights that £1bn in cuts are still to come by 2020. He vows to protect key priorities like schools, hospitals, and police, emphasizing Scotland's achievements in public services. The UK government counters that Scotland benefits from the stability of the UK economy, while Labour criticizes Swinney for not offering a long-term budget and calls for an alternative to austerity.

**Summary:**  
Many individuals with severe disabilities and their carers face significant challenges due to the lack of truly accessible toilet facilities, often feeling isolated and unable to participate in everyday activities. While standard accessible toilets cater to some, those requiring additional support, such as hoists or space for two carers, are often left without suitable options. **Changing Places toilets**, which offer enhanced features and more space, are recommended in larger buildings like shopping centres and cinemas but are not yet compulsory. Campaigners, including Lorna Fillingham (who started a petition) and Alison Beevers, highlight the psychological and practical impact of inadequate facilities, emphasizing the need for legislative change. Currently, there are only 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, despite over a quarter of a million people needing them. Efforts are focused on making these facilities mandatory in new larger complexes, with examples like Arsenal Football Club demonstrating positive outcomes from installation. Logistical and financial barriers exist, but advocates argue that compulsory regulations would provide clarity and ensure inclusivity for all.

Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging the company forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, restricts their ability to switch to competitors through long-term contracts, and leases premises at above-market rates. This, they claim, results in poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to company-owned outlets. Supported by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions, the complaint argues McDonald's abuses its dominant market position, harming franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed founded. McDonald's defends its practices, stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees, fostering successful business opportunities and customer experiences. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, contributing $9.27 billion in global franchised revenues in 2014.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh has gone viral in support of 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign, initiated by Bangor Elim Church where Josh's father works, has garnered global attention, with a mystery donor funding a large billboard in Holywood. The hashtag, shared over 948 times and viewed by 79,000 people, has united Josh's community, classmates, and strangers worldwide in praying for his recovery.

The UK government is reorganizing military buildings and relocating regiments, including the closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic site since 1805. Brecon MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the decision, citing its rich military history and local economic impact, and plans to petition against it. The closure is part of a broader restructuring, which includes creating a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan and delaying the closure of Cawdor Barracks until 2024. While jobs at Brecon Barracks are not expected to be at risk, the move raises concerns about the town's military tourism and local livelihoods. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports estate restructuring but highlights the uncertainty for affected communities.

The passage discusses the complexities of the UK fishing industry post-Brexit, highlighting both opportunities and risks. Key points include:

1. **Fishing Industry's Role in Brexit**: Fishing regions strongly supported leaving the EU, driven by dissatisfaction with the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which they view as detrimental to UK interests.

2. **Economic Significance**: Despite contributing only 0.5% to UK GDP and employing 12,000 fishers, the industry holds symbolic importance and must not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations.

3. **Trade-Offs in Negotiations**: The UK may need to allow EU boats access to its waters in exchange for continued tariff-free access to the EU fish market, a potential compromise for the industry.

4. **Shared Waters and Exports**: Most UK fish stocks are in shared waters, and the majority of UK fish is exported to the EU, while much of the fish consumed in the UK is imported, emphasizing the need for market access.

5. **CFP Retention and International Obligations**: The House of Lords report suggests retaining certain CFP elements, such as science-based quotas, and highlights ongoing international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states.

6. **Regional Management Concerns**: Leaving the EU could lead to four separate fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland, complicating governance.

7. **Optimism in the Industry**: Despite risks, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic, citing recent quota increases under the CFP and the potential for greater control over UK waters post-Brexit.

8. **Government Stance**: The UK government aims to secure maximum trade freedom while reviewing fisheries management to ensure sustainability, fair quotas, and a healthy marine environment.

**Summary:**

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks exposing extensive U.S. surveillance programs. The leaks detail the National Security Agency (NSA) accessing vast amounts of personal data, including chat logs, phone records, and social media activity, through programs like Prism, which allegedly provided "backdoor" access to major tech companies' servers. While U.S. officials, including President Obama and NSA Director Keith Alexander, defend these measures as necessary for national security, critics and privacy advocates express concerns about the erosion of privacy rights. The revelations highlight global data storage practices, the reach of U.S. laws like the Patriot Act, and the secretive nature of government surveillance, sparking international debate and calls for transparency. Snowden stated he acted to protect privacy, fearing a world where all actions are recorded.

OpenAI, backed by prominent figures like Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to advance artificial intelligence research with a focus on benefiting humanity, free from financial constraints. The venture addresses concerns about AI's potential existential threat to humanity, as warned by figures like Musk and Stephen Hawking, while acknowledging that some experts view the risk as remote. OpenAI's mission is to develop AI that enhances society, ensures safety, and is broadly accessible, with a $1 billion pledge to support long-term research.

Ben Parkinson, a Doncaster-based L/Bdr seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on June 26, supported by an assistant. Despite a brain injury affecting his speech, he retains his personality, humor, and determination, spending 12 hours daily in rehab and fundraising for military charities, including as patron of Pilgrim Bandits. His torch-bearing moment drew immense support, with over 5,000 Facebook friend requests (exceeding the platform’s limit) and 19,000 hits on an update. His mother, Diane, highlighted the overwhelming response, including increased mail and requests for visits. Facebook suggested transitioning to a public figure page or using subscriptions to manage his growing following. Parkinson’s story exemplifies resilience and community support, as he joins 8,000 torchbearers in the 8,000-mile journey to the London 2012 Olympic Games opening ceremony.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, after three years of increases. Real median household income declined by 1.5%, and the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality rose by 1.6% as measured by the Gini index, the first annual increase since 1993. The uninsured rate decreased slightly to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty had peaked at a record 15.1% in 2010.

A 25-year-old cricketer, Jos Buttler, has signed a new deal with Lancashire (Red Rose) until 2019, after moving from Somerset in 2013. Known as a short-format specialist, Buttler holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Praised by cricket director Ashley Giles for his talent, impact in the T20 Blast final, and international experience, Buttler will return to Lancashire from the Indian Premier League for a T20 Blast game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, HMS Cornwall) are up for sale, with bids finalized by late February/March and a decision expected in spring. The UK government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess domestic industry capacity, though no preservation proposals have been submitted. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, advocates for saving at least one ship, suggesting a reef and diving attraction for tourism revenue. The Ministry of Defence prioritizes the best financial return for taxpayers, with commercial sensitivity preventing disclosure of bid details. These frigates, originally anti-submarine specialists, evolved into versatile surface combatants with advanced weapons systems and command capabilities, crewed by approximately 280 personnel.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant instability due to racial and political tensions, marked by coups in 1987, 2000, and 2006. These events, including the 2000 coup led by George Speight, severely damaged the economy, particularly tourism, and international reputation. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 for lack of democratic progress but reinstated after free elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with indigenous Fijians now holding a slight majority due to Indo-Fijian emigration. Society remains largely segregated. Fiji's economy relies on sugar, tourism, mining, services, and light manufacturing but faces trade and budget deficits, making it a major recipient of foreign aid.

Syria is working to meet the deadline for destroying its chemical weapons, but missed the initial deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad cited security challenges, including attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups," and emphasized Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and UN. The U.S. expressed concern over the delay, with only 4% of the stockpile removed so far. Meanwhile, tensions escalated over the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which activists claim have killed hundreds of civilians, including children. The government denies targeting civilians and accuses the U.S. of supporting terrorists. Additionally, conflicting reports emerged regarding rebel control of Aleppo's central prison, with the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and rebel groups claiming success, while state media denies it. Syria has approximately 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with a deadline for complete destruction by the end of June.

The 2014 Booker Prize, now open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality, features a diverse shortlist including Mukherjee's *The Lives of Others* (5/2 favorite), Howard Jacobson's *J*, Ali Smith's *How to Be Both*, Joshua Ferris's *To Rise Again at a Decent Hour*, Karen Joy Fowler's *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves*, and Richard Flanagan's *The Narrow Road to the Deep North*. Fowler's novel is the best-selling, with over 55,000 copies sold. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, with the shortlisted authors receiving £2,500 and a special edition of their book. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling, and the ceremony will be covered by the BBC.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his being named in the media in England and Wales. The case centers on PJS's alleged extra-marital activities, which The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish. PJS argues he has a right to privacy. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant an appeal and, if so, whether to allow or dismiss it. An interim injunction preventing publication remains in place until the hearing concludes. The Court of Appeal previously ruled that confidentiality had likely been lost due to widespread online dissemination of the story, making a permanent injunction unlikely.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and purchased for £345.5m in August, is set for improvements to address parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of its units. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White confirmed discussions with the new owners to resolve planning concerns, emphasizing the park's role as a gateway to the city. Crown Estates director Paul Clarke highlighted plans to enhance common areas, parking facilities, and overall quality, acknowledging the park's recent decline.

The live-action remake of *Beauty and the Beast* faced controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving the character LeFou. Disney delayed its release for a content review, and the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit to the scene, granting it a P13 parental guidance classification. Despite approval, a new release date remains pending, and local cinemas offered refunds for pre-purchased tickets. The decision sparked criticism from netizens, who deemed it "stupid and laughable," contrasting it with the acceptance of morally questionable local films. Homosexual activity is illegal in Muslim-majority Malaysia, though the tourism minister called banning the film "ridiculous."

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated people must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which costs £1,000, or face fines up to £20,000. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. HMO tenants often face eviction fears and poor living conditions due to a shortage of affordable housing. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to properties with five or more unrelated occupants in three-storey or larger houses. In Southampton, licensing affects specific areas under two designations (2013 and 2015). While most landlords comply, some resist licensing, with the council prosecuting one firm and 13 individuals so far.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) aim to prevent a second election. Fianna Fáil will allow a minority government but won’t back a programme for government. Water charges are a key obstacle, with Fianna Fáil demanding their immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting their retention. A commission to review Irish Water’s future is under consideration. Post-election results: Fine Gael (50 seats), Fianna Fáil (44), Sinn Féin (23), Labour (7). No party secured a majority, and TDs have yet to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento ferry, en route to Valencia, caught fire on a car deck 27km from Mallorca, leading to a full evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and were airlifted to a hospital. Rescued by another ship, the Puglia, the passengers were returning to Palma de Mallorca, with psychologists awaiting their arrival. The cause of the fire remains unclear, and the ship may sink due to the damage. The ferry, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, initially sent distress signals at 13:50 local time, with the situation escalating to require a complete evacuation.

Here’s a concise summary of the passage:

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs flagged instances of individuals, including students, allegedly voting twice, a criminal offense. A record 46.8 million people registered for the June 8 election, with 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. Despite 4.9 million applications submitted between December 1, 2016, and May 22, 2017, the net increase in the electoral register was only 1.4 million, indicating significant duplicate applications (30-70% in some areas). The lack of integration between local electoral registers and the online registration system exacerbates the issue. The Commission recommends clearer registration information, a verification function, and improved cross-checking of registers to reduce duplicates and prevent double voting. Labour cautioned against measures that could hinder young voters' registration, emphasizing the need to balance integrity with accessibility.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and University of Nebraska star, died at age 40, with officials believing he committed suicide. Phillips, who played for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers in the 1990s, had a troubled career and post-career life marked by legal issues, including convictions for assault and domestic violence. Serving a 30-year prison sentence, he was recently accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, and was awaiting trial. His former coach, Tom Osborne, acknowledged Phillips' intelligence and potential but noted his struggles with anger and personal demons. The method of his suicide remains unclear.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester celebrating the Mercian Regiment's eight-year anniversary. Awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams, the promotion recognizes his "good behaviour." Derby XXX is the 30th in a lineage of mascot rams dating back to the mid-19th century, originating with the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot in 1858. He joined the Mercian Regiment in 2014, holds an army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. His notable duties include turning on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarter-final, advancing to the semi-finals. The match, filled with emotion, excitement, and brilliant football, saw Liverpool overcome a 2-0 deficit in the first nine minutes, eventually winning with Dejan Lovren's injury-time header. The game was a testament to Liverpool's resilience and manager Jurgen Klopp's inspirational leadership, echoing the spirit of their 2005 Champions League comeback. The win moves Liverpool closer to a Champions League spot and reinforces Klopp's impact on the team and fans, transforming doubters into believers. The match also highlighted individual performances, such as Divock Origi's growing influence and Philippe Coutinho's brilliance, while exposing defensive vulnerabilities that Klopp may address. The victory, set against a vibrant Anfield atmosphere, cements Liverpool's potential to win the Europa League and return to the Champions League.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London to discuss Brexit negotiations and collaboration between the UK government and devolved administrations (Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland). Key points include:  
1. **UK Commitment**: David Davis pledged to keep devolved nations informed and proposed monthly meetings for two-way information sharing.  
2. **Devolved Concerns**: Michael Russell emphasized the need for transparency, particularly on the UK’s stance on the single market and customs union, critical for Scotland’s economic interests.  
3. **Legal Context**: The UK government aims to overturn the High Court’s Article 50 ruling in the Supreme Court, while the Scottish government plans to oppose this appeal.  
4. **Collaborative Intent**: Both sides acknowledged constructive dialogue but highlighted differing priorities and the need for clarity in the UK’s negotiating strategy.

The passage describes a study examining the health and aging of cloned sheep, including four clones (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) genetically identical to Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal. These sheep, along with nine others cloned from different cell lines, are undergoing rigorous physical examinations, joint X-rays, and full-body fMRI scans to assess their health, particularly focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis—conditions associated with aging. The study aims to determine if cloned animals age normally or if the cloning process accelerates aging. Concerns stem from the possibility that cloned animals might inherit "age-memory" from the donor cell, leading to premature aging. The results, which could significantly impact the future of cloning, are pending publication, but the sheep, now approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, appear healthy.

The passage highlights several key horse racing events and decisions:

1. **Unbeaten Favourite Wins**: Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten favourite won by a length and three quarters, bypassing the Oaks at Epsom in favor of Chantilly.  
2. **Duke of York Stakes**: Tasleet (14-1), trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, won comfortably ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas.  
3. **Shutter Speed's Musidora Win**: Shutter Speed, trained by Gosden and ridden by Dettori, secured a fifth Musidora win despite soft ground. She will head to France's Oaks instead of Epsom.  
4. **Gosden's Epsom Oaks Contenders**: Enable and Coronet are Gosden's top contenders for the Epsom Oaks.  
5. **Cracksman's Uncertain Dante Stakes Entry**: Gosden is concerned about the ground for Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and may skip the Derby trial due to the short gap before the Derby.  

**Summary**: Gosden’s unbeaten favorite and Shutter Speed secured wins, with the latter heading to France’s Oaks. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, while Gosden’s Epsom Oaks focus remains on Enable and Coronet. Cracksman’s Dante Stakes participation is uncertain due to ground concerns.

The passage discusses the British pound's volatility amid Brexit referendum uncertainty, with the currency fluctuating against the dollar, euro, and yen. The "volatility index" reached 2008 financial crisis levels, reflecting investor unease. Polls showed the Leave campaign gaining ground, reducing the probability of a Remain vote from 80% to 68.5%. Markets reacted nervously, with sterling shedding over 2% in two sessions and Asian stock markets falling sharply. The FTSE 100 closed down 1.1%, led by declines in Lloyds Banking Group. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued a weaker pound benefits UK exporters, citing a narrowed trade deficit in April. Analysts predict further sterling volatility as polls tighten ahead of the vote.

The Iron sit sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-offs. Despite a recent losing streak, manager Cowley remains positive, praising his part-time team's achievements and acknowledging the challenge ahead. Barrow extended their unbeaten run to nine games with a victory over Braintree, who are now on a three-game losing streak. Cowley emphasizes the team's determination to embrace the challenge and enjoy the journey.

The passage discusses a significant shift in Northern Ireland's planning system, where local councils will gain the authority to make most planning decisions, including approving or rejecting developments, starting April 2015. This change aims to democratize the planning process by giving elected politicians more control. Supporters, like Michael Corr from PLACE, see it as an opportunity for councils to develop community-focused plans. However, critics, such as Friends of the Earth, warn of potential risks, including historical biases in decision-making, close ties between developers and politicians, and the need for transparency to prevent favoritism. Concerns also arise about the financial implications for developers and the importance of disclosing political donations. Some politicians oppose the move, citing security concerns for donors. The Northern Ireland Secretary will decide when to implement greater transparency in political donations.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie survived after being shot three times, requiring amputation of her left back leg. Found by her owner in Winchburgh, the cat is now learning to walk again. The incident highlights concerns over airgun safety, with the Scottish SPCA advocating for urgent licensing of airguns to prevent further harm. Despite a Scottish government consultation on air weapon licensing, 87% of respondents opposed the plan, deeming it excessive. The charity urges anyone with information about the shooting to come forward.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for a fee making him their second most expensive player, aiming to boost their goal-scoring after a lackluster season. Benteke, a 24-year-old Belgium international, joins on a long-term contract, becoming the club's seventh summer signing. He scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa and is expected to revive Liverpool's attack, alongside other new forwards like Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Former managers and players, including Paul Lambert and John Aldridge, believe Benteke's strength, speed, and goal-scoring ability will significantly enhance Liverpool's squad.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, found no clear evidence of academic improvement linked to tablet use in schools, despite their widespread adoption (68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools). Tablet use is highest in academy schools, and their presence in schools is expected to double from 430,000 to 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. While researchers couldn't isolate technology as the sole cause of improved results, headteachers reported positive impacts, including increased pupil motivation and family involvement. A separate study highlighted touch-screen computers' effectiveness in helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The research also revealed high technology integration in young people's lives, with a quarter of secondary pupils in fully tablet-equipped schools identifying as internet "addicts" and two-thirds taking devices to bed for social media or videos. Despite challenges in quantifying benefits, educators like Simon Mason advocate for tablets, citing their portability, empowerment of students, and alignment with modern realities.

The exhibition *Growing Up in the City* at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, capturing childhood experiences and Liverpool's social history. The images depict both play and work, highlighting changes in children's lives and special occasions. Notable photos include the Rollo family in 1887 and a young maid around 1900. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibition was selected from hundreds of images to showcase the diverse experiences of childhood, balancing both happy and challenging memories. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join a rival National League club, potentially facing his former team on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams, joins the Gulls pending international clearance, with manager Kevin Nicholson praising Anderson's leadership and Keating's potential. The team, four points above relegation, has won only one of their last six games.

The new Bolivian law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic realities. It also imposes stricter penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera emphasized balancing local needs with international treaties. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia already work to support their families, often in harsh conditions. The government aims to address extreme poverty through this law, despite it potentially conflicting with International Labour Organisation (ILO) regulations, which set a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries. The ILO is reviewing the legislation for compliance with international standards.

Rosie O'Donnell, 50, survived a severe heart attack after recognizing her symptoms online, including nausea and aches, and taking aspirin. She later visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery, identifying the attack as the "widow maker." O'Donnell, known for roles in *Drop Dead Diva*, *Will and Grace*, and *Nip/Tuck*, did not call emergency services but urged women to know heart attack symptoms and seek immediate help. She recently hosted *The Rosie Show*, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed in an alleyway in Kenton after attending a party on Saturday evening. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed but remains in stable condition. Police believe Che was targeted later, despite not being involved in an earlier altercation with youths denied entry to the party. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder, while a 14-year-old is held for possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage describes a healthcare reorganization in Denmark aimed at improving cancer diagnosis and survival rates, particularly for cases with vague or non-obvious symptoms. Key issues included long waiting times and delayed diagnoses. The new model introduced three routes:  
1. **Fast-track diagnosis** for patients with "alarm" symptoms, with strict time targets.  
2. **Diagnosis centres** for patients with undiagnosed symptoms, offering quick tests and scans to identify issues, including cancer.  
3. **"Yes-no" centres** for patients with minor symptoms, providing rapid tests to rule out serious diseases.  
The changes have improved survival rates without overwhelming the system, fostering better collaboration between GPs and specialists. Wales, with a similar health system, is exploring lessons from Denmark to enhance its own cancer care.

The UK government has disbanded the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) and awarded Powys council a £170,000 annual contract to oversee estate agent regulation. Powys will issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest or non-compliant agents, replacing the OFT's role. Complaints will still be handled by local trading standards departments, which will refer cases to Powys if breaches of the Estate Agents Act are suspected. James Munro, leading the new team, sees this as an opportunity for Powys to take on more external contracts in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the NHS workforce, supported by a Nuffield Trust review that identified opportunities for nurses and other staff to take on additional roles with further training. The review highlighted examples of nurses substituting for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs, addressing gaps in junior doctor rotas and GP workloads. The plan aims to improve patient care, particularly for long-term conditions, and provide more rewarding roles for staff. However, unions caution against using this as a quick fix for NHS staffing shortages, emphasizing the need for proper funding for training and the irreplaceable expertise of doctors. NHS Employers aims to implement the report's recommendations, while stakeholders stress the importance of balancing workforce development with maintaining high-quality medical training and support.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath after a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing significant disruption to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, but it will take several hours for all bus services to return to normal. Investigations into the collision are ongoing, and First Bus expressed gratitude to the public and staff for their support and efforts during the recovery process.

The passage discusses a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) over the environmental impact of the proposed £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project. NRW estimates that the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying annually during migration, based on what it claims is the "best available evidence." TLP disputes these figures, arguing they lack a "clear scientific basis" and criticizing NRW for not sharing its methodology. TLP's own computer modeling suggests a "worst-case scenario" of 2% fish mortality. The project is seen as a test bed for larger, more cost-effective lagoons in other locations. UK government ministers are reviewing the scheme's viability, while the Welsh Government supports it but seeks clarity from the UK government soon. NRW defends its findings, stating they are based on extensive evidence and independent expert assessments.

Northern Ireland is establishing a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, announced by DETI Minister Arlene Foster, to enhance the sector's strategic leadership and coordination. The body, modeled after Scotland Food and Drink, aims to benefit the entire agri-food industry, which supports nearly 100,000 jobs. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the initiative but noted potential implications for existing organizations and called for further discussions with the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB).

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon as part of a four-year project to plant "millions" of native UK trees in memory of those who died in WW1. The initiative, themed "We will stand for those who fell," aims to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood to honor the 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The event invites locals and visitors to participate, with the goal of creating a space for wildlife, reflection, and remembrance. The charity provides saplings and encourages volunteers to wear sturdy footwear. Brackfield Wood, located near Derry city, will feature native trees and wildflowers, including poppies, serving as a lasting tribute to those affected by the war.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for *Someone Else's Skin*, a thriller addressing domestic violence and honor crimes, praised for its emotional power and tight writing. The award was presented at Harrogate's annual crime writing festival. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career creating detective VI Warshawski, a groundbreaking female protagonist, and for founding Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally. The festival, chaired by Ann Cleeves, highlighted a strong shortlist and celebrated Paretsky's impact on crime fiction.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, will rejoin Worcestershire Rapids in 2017 after a finger injury cut short his 2016 season. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, expressed frustration over the injury but is eager to make an impact with both bat and ball upon his return. Worcestershire's director of cricket, Steve Rhodes, highlighted Santner's potential as a key player, noting the team's strong start in 2016 was hindered by his absence. Additionally, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was unlawfully killed in a staged hit-and-run accident in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi on a dual carriageway. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (Anna), 19 years his junior, was suspected of involvement due to her quick attempts to claim his assets and evidence of an affair. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, concluded the killing was deliberate, citing overwhelming circumstantial evidence, including a speeding car with stolen plates and no braking. Pring’s family believes Ziuzina orchestrated the murder for financial gain. The Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011, though it remains unresolved. Ziuzina did not attend the inquest, claiming she had already provided statements to Ukrainian police.

Charlie, a boy from Merseyside, urgently needs experimental T-Cell Therapy in Seattle, USA, after his last transplant failed and UK treatment options were exhausted. His mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed overwhelming gratitude to an anonymous donor who paid for the treatment, enabling Charlie to receive it as soon as possible. The family, previously heartbroken by the first transplant's failure, is now relieved and thankful for the generosity, with Charlie's treatment set to begin imminently.

Apple has implemented a two-factor authentication system to enhance iCloud security following the theft of celebrities' intimate photos. This system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after logging in from a new device, preventing unauthorized access even if passwords are compromised. While this measure blocks tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, it remains an opt-in feature, with experts advocating for it to be the default setting. Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, acknowledging the need for increased security awareness. Concerns remain about the recovery key's vulnerability to loss or theft, but Apple is taking steps to improve overall security.

Mark Wright is in talks to buy a 20% stake in Billericay Town FC and become a club director. The club, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has invested heavily. Billericay recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright, a reality TV star and former non-league footballer, played for clubs like Lewes and Crawley Town.

The passage discusses the request for Mike Ashley, owner of Sports Direct, to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse practices. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, sent a letter to Ashley, inviting him to a public meeting at Westminster. Ashley had previously proposed a meeting at the company's Shirebrook base but did not accept alternative dates offered by the committee. The committee warned that failure to agree to attend could lead to further action, including a potential contempt complaint to the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not commented, but previously pledged to review worker rights under Ashley's oversight.

The passage summarizes efforts by Russian opposition figures, led by Ilya Yashin, to complete a report titled *Putin. War*, originally initiated by the murdered politician Boris Nemtsov. The report compiles evidence from Russian and foreign media, accusing President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for personal gain. It highlights Russia’s alleged use of regular troops and equipment to support pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine, despite official denials. The dossier includes testimonies from soldiers, details of Russian military involvement, and estimates of financial costs. Challenges in publishing and distributing the report are noted, as many fear repercussions. The opposition aims to expose Putin’s role in the conflict, though previous critical reports by Nemtsov failed to spark significant protests. The report’s impact remains uncertain, given public apathy and support for Putin’s actions in Ukraine.

Craig Nelson (also known as Craig Preston), 34, from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found deceased at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. A post-mortem revealed he died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

The passage highlights tensions between the UK government and devolved administrations, particularly Wales, over the Article 50 letter triggering Brexit. Key points include:

1. **Lack of Consultation**: Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones criticized not being consulted on the letter's drafting, calling it "unacceptable" and part of a pattern of disrespect toward devolved governments.  
2. **UK Government's Response**: Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the process, noting ongoing discussions and the UK government's duty to act in the interest of the whole UK.  
3. **Devolution of Powers**: Prime Minister Theresa May pledged to consult on devolving powers post-Brexit, promising a "significant increase" in decision-making for devolved administrations. However, specifics (e.g., farming, economic aid) and funding remain unclear.  
4. **Funding Concerns**: Carwyn Jones expressed fears that devolved powers might not come with adequate funding after 2020, contrasting with Labour’s pledge to maintain EU funding levels.  
5. **Uncertainty**: The identity of powers to be devolved and the process remain a mystery, with expectations of further details in the Great Repeal Bill white paper.  

The passage underscores ongoing political friction and uncertainty surrounding Brexit’s impact on devolved nations.

In the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, two cars were damaged in an incident where PSNI officers were attacked while carrying out their duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed appalment at the "mindless attacks" on both the officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page appealed to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

The passage details the ousting of American Apparel founder Mr. Charney due to employee complaints, accusations of misusing company funds, and evidence of inappropriate behavior, including illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts. The company's board filed court documents asserting he will not return and highlighting violations of company policies. Mr. Charney's lawyer denies the claims, accusing the company of invading his privacy and extortion. The company obtained a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements or attempting to remove board members.

The upcoming basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Greece previously defeated GB 92-64 in Patras, Greece, but three key Greek players will be absent in the rematch at the Copper Box in London. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing in his hometown and emphasized the importance of the game as preparation for FIBA EuroBasket 2017. This match is GB's only home game before the tournament, which begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey. After facing Greece, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up. The game is scheduled for 17:30-19:30 BST.

The passage reflects on the transformative impact of the iPhone's launch in 2007, initially met with skepticism and criticism for its media coverage. The author recounts securing an early look at the iPhone from Apple’s marketing chief, Phil Schiller, and using it for a news piece, despite complaints of undue prominence. The iPhone, initially compared to revolutionary innovations like the Model T Ford, has proven to be a key technology of the last decade, putting powerful computers in the hands of billions and disrupting industries. It revolutionized photography and mobile activities by combining functionality with an attractive user interface, making it accessible to a broader audience. Despite initial reservations, the author now acknowledges the iPhone’s historical significance as the catalyst for the mobile connected era, paving the way for AI-driven innovations by companies like Amazon and Google.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, multiple cats near Victor Avenue have died from ingesting a toxic substance, confirmed as antifreeze. The most recent victim was seven-month-old Meereen, who died on Monday after showing symptoms of poisoning. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings are accidental or deliberate. Four other cats in the area have died in the past two weeks. Meereen’s owner, Adria Pearce, expressed devastation over the loss. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock urges residents to store chemicals safely and check for antifreeze leaks or spills, especially during the current season of increased antifreeze use.

The passage discusses the lack of public protests in Athens despite the Syriza government's impending implementation of additional austerity and liberalization measures mandated by creditors. Greece's tourism sector is thriving, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year, up from 21 million. The absence of widespread demonstrations may be due to the recent economic crisis, which has led the government to adopt a "there is no alternative" (TINA) stance. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and causing monetary austerity through bank closures. Greece faces a severe economic squeeze, with businesses struggling to access credit, threatening economic activity. The new €86 billion bailout, the third for Greece, hinges on Tsipras offering hope for recovery. Creditors, particularly Brussels and Berlin, must provide debt forgiveness to ensure a genuine path to recovery and avoid triumphalism.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in *EastEnders* from 1990-1999 and briefly in 2005-2006, is returning for Barbara Windsor’s (Dame Peggy Mitchell) final episodes. Peggy, who returned to Albert Square to reveal her terminal cancer, will die in emotional scenes airing in the spring. Kemp’s return reunites the Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil (Steve McFadden), as they say goodbye to their mother. Known for his iconic role in the soap’s 30-year history, Grant’s return promises classic *EastEnders* episodes, showcasing the Mitchell family’s dramatic dynamics and the actors’ strong performances.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon when informed of her death. Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice, 24, and had stalked her. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice that the situation would be okay, despite her daughter Emma’s warnings that Dhillon would kill her. Alice’s parents now run the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers, hoping she is remembered for her vibrant personality. Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

The UK government has delayed its final decision on the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project in Somerset, despite French firm EDF's board approving the funding. The project, expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity, faces criticism over environmental concerns, escalating costs, and foreign involvement, with one-third of the funding coming from Chinese investors. The delay, announced shortly after EDF's approval, has caused uncertainty and raised questions about policy changes or further review. Key stakeholders, including the Nuclear Industry Association and EEF, urge swift government action to avoid energy supply risks and increased costs. The project has also faced internal EDF challenges, with resignations over financial risks and the need to raise additional funds. Environmentalists advocate for more investment in renewable energy instead.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales includes a field for naming the person a spouse committed adultery with, though it’s not mandatory. Family lawyers warn this can increase conflict and complexity, potentially delaying proceedings and adding costs if the third party is involved. The form’s guidance notes it’s "not normally necessary" to name the individual, but concerns remain that users may feel compelled to fill it in. The Ministry of Justice emphasizes there’s no obligation to provide this information, and judges generally disapprove of involving third parties in divorce proceedings. Adultery was cited in 12,148 of over 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales in 2015, with "unreasonable behaviour" being the most common reason.

The passage discusses the tension between environmental policies and the timber industry in Wales. While ministers emphasize native, broadleaf tree species and public access, the forestry industry, represented by Confor, argues that commercial forests are essential for the economy. Key points include:

1. **Timber Industry Concerns**: Confor warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001, necessitating replanting to meet demand.  
2. **Economic Impact**: Forestry contributes over £450 million annually to the Welsh economy, but faces challenges like accessibility and community conflicts during timber transport.  
3. **Policy Conflict**: Environmental policies favoring native species and recreational access clash with commercial forestry needs.  
4. **Welsh Government’s Approach**: The government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social aspects through initiatives like the Glastir scheme and the Woodlands for Wales strategy.  
5. **Industry Perspective**: Confor’s Martin Bishop criticizes the bureaucratic process for creating new woodland areas and emphasizes the unmet demand for timber, calling for increased planting to meet long-term targets.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street around 16:40. Emergency crews responded, and the boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is described as serious.

The passage details the recognition of British veterans of the Arctic Convoys during World War II, who braved harsh conditions and German attacks to resupply the Soviet Union. Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko awarded the Ushakov Medal to veterans like 91-year-old Able Seaman Charles Lewis, honoring their contributions to the war effort. Initially, the Foreign Office blocked the Russian award due to rules on foreign medals, but an exception was made in 2013, allowing President Vladimir Putin to present the medals. The Arctic Convoys, deemed by Winston Churchill as the "worst journey in the world," resulted in the loss of 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen killed. The Ushakov Medal symbolizes Russia's gratitude for the veterans' role in defeating the Germans on the Eastern Front.

HM Inspectorate of Probation's report highlights significant delays and enforcement issues in the UK's community payback scheme, where offenders perform unpaid work as an alternative to imprisonment. Key findings include:

- **Delays and Non-Attendance**: Offenders often start work late, and many face no consequences for non-attendance, with one case completing only 16 hours in 17 months.  
- **Scheme Details**: Offenders perform 40 to 300 hours of unpaid work for offenses like theft or drug crimes, with 70,000 ordered in 2014.  
- **Historical Context**: The 2007 re-branding as "community payback" aimed to boost public confidence, but organizational challenges persist.  
- **Recommendations**: The report suggests reducing instances of offenders being turned away and tailoring work to their circumstances, with 15 recommendations for improvement.  
- **Positive Aspects**: Inspectors praised high-quality work and offenders gaining skills, with many viewing their sentences positively.  
- **Response**: The Ministry of Justice accepted all recommendations, pledging to ensure timely attendance and enforce consequences for non-compliance.  

The report underscores the need for urgent action to improve the scheme's effectiveness and rehabilitation focus.

The passage discusses criticism of comedian Russell Brand, who is labeled a "hypocrite" by *The Sun* for advocating economic and political "revolution" to aid the poor while living in a luxury London home. This accusation is not new, and Brand has previously acknowledged his wealth and fame, admitting the need for personal and systemic change. He argues that his privileged position doesn't invalidate his concerns about economic inequality and ecological disaster. Brand has faced similar critiques before and responded by emphasizing the importance of addressing inequality, despite personal contradictions. The article also mentions his reaction to a reporter's question about his rent, his use of the hashtag #TheSunLogic on Twitter, and his broader reflections on hypocrisy and societal issues.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the mapping of the human genome through a competitive approach, despite criticism from the scientific community for his methods and perceived arrogance. His work significantly sped up genomic research, leading to the publication of the human genome and the creation of the first synthetic life form, Synthia, detailed in the journal *Science*. Venter's career began with a transformative experience in Vietnam, which instilled a sense of urgency in his work. He pioneered automated gene sequencing and founded Celera Genomics to decode the human genome in three years, challenging the public project's timeline. Despite controversy over his commercial approach and data access, Venter's financial success allowed him to pursue ambitious projects independently, including synthetic biology and ocean microbial research. His synthetic life breakthrough aims to revolutionize industries and address environmental challenges, though it remains contentious.

Researchers surveyed 1,000 parents in England and found that 80% of children who ate school lunches tried new foods they hadn’t eaten at home, with 50% of parents reporting their children requested these foods be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least favored. England’s School Food Trust commissioned the study after concerns about picky eating, emphasizing that school meals encourage children to try new, healthier foods. Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton noted positive peer pressure in schools promotes dietary variety. School meals now adhere to strict nutritional guidelines, with about 40% of primary school children in England eating them, compared to 46% in Scotland. The survey was conducted online in late February to early March among parents of school-aged children (4-17 years).

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, moved to Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. The transfer included a buy-back option for Real, reportedly up to €30 million (£23m). Morata has scored 27 goals in two years at Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in two consecutive Champions League finals. He previously scored 10 goals for Real Madrid and has netted three times for Spain at Euro 2016. Morata, a product of Real's youth system, has also been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, rejoined Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, marking his second spell at the club. He made 51 appearances during this period, adding to his previous four seasons with Forest. Wilson has also played for Preston North End and Notts County. He was released in May and is currently without a team.
